question_text: Why does the phase of the flame transfer function become fixed to multiples of π at marginal stability in systems with fully reflecting boundary conditions, and how does this constrain the oscillation frequency?
standard_answer: In systems with fully reflecting boundary conditions (e.g., closed inlet and open outlet), the jump conditions and acoustic wave propagation impose a real-valued constraint on the flame response at marginal stability (σ = 0). The combined equations from momentum and energy conservation across the flame and boundaries lead to the relation 1 + θF(ω) = (ξ/α) cot(φ₂) cot(φ₀ + φₑ + φ₁), where the right-hand side is purely real. Since F(ω) = |F(ω)|e^(iφ), this necessitates that the phase φ must be an integer multiple of π (φ = -kπ for k ∈ N₀) to ensure the left-hand side is also real. Consequently, the oscillation frequency ω is determined solely by the phase condition φ(ω) = -kπ, which for an n-τ model F(s) = ne^(-iωτ) implies ω = kπ/τ. This phase locking occurs because the acoustic field's symmetry under full reflection forces the heat release fluctuations to be in phase or anti-phase with velocity perturbations, eliminating imaginary components in the stability criterion.
